verses.text: Hear us, Shepherd of Israel, you who lead Joseph like a flock; you who sit enthroned between the cherubim, shine forth.
verses.comment: This verse appeals to God as the Shepherd, an image tied to both the leadership of Israel and, christologically, to Jesus as the Good Shepherd (John 10:11). The one enthroned between the cherubim points to God’s dwelling in the Holy of Holies, anticipating the future manifestation of His presence in Jesus.

verses.text: Before Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasseh, stir up your might and come to save us.
verses.comment: The tribes listed are those closest to the sanctuary when Israel camped. The call invokes God’s saving power in the visible assembly, reflecting the importance of worship together as a community.

verses.text: Restore us, O God; let your face shine upon us, that we may be saved.
verses.comment: The prayer for restoration and God's shining face recalls the priestly blessing. This is a foreshadowing of the grace and salvation made fully manifest in Christ, whose face is the radiance of God (Heb. 1:3).

verses.text: O LORD God of Hosts, how long will you be angry with your people’s prayers?
verses.comment: God as 'Lord of Hosts' highlights His rule over all angelic powers. The lament about unanswered prayer is both personal and communal, reminiscent of Israel’s times of suffering and longing for God's mercy.

verses.text: You have fed them with the bread of tears and made them drink tears in full measure.
verses.comment: The bread and cup imagery of sorrow echoes themes of suffering, prefiguring the compassion and comfort ultimately offered through Christ’s passion and the mystery of redemptive suffering.

verses.text: You make us a source of contention for our neighbors, and our enemies laugh among themselves.
verses.comment: Israel’s humiliation among nations highlights consequences of covenant infidelity, calling readers toward repentance and restoration as a united people in faith.

verses.text: Restore us, O God of Hosts; let your face shine upon us, that we may be saved.
verses.comment: Repeated refrain emphasizes communal intercession and the transformation that comes from God's presence. This foreshadows the restoring work of Christ and the importance of sacred liturgical prayer.

verses.text: You brought a vine out of Egypt; you drove out the nations and planted it.
verses.comment: The vine symbolizes Israel, transplanted and nurtured by God. In the New Testament, Jesus refers to Himself as the true Vine (John 15:1), fulfilling the imagery of God’s people united in Him.

verses.text: You cleared the ground for it, and it took deep root and filled the land.
verses.comment: God’s preparation of the land and rooting of His people reflects Divine Providence, and points to spiritual growth and the fruitfulness of abiding in Christ.

verses.text: The mountains were covered with its shade, and the mighty cedars with its branches.
verses.comment: Israel’s flourishing is described in terms of cosmic growth, reminiscent of the Kingdom’s expansive influence—fulfilled in the spiritual kingdom Christ establishes.

verses.text: It sent out its branches to the sea, and its shoots to the River.
verses.comment: The geographical spread notes God’s promise of inheritance, later spiritualized by Christ’s call to make disciples of all nations (Matthew 28:19).

verses.text: Why then have you broken down its walls, so that all who pass by pick its fruit?
verses.comment: The breach of protection reflects Divine judgment. It points to the necessity of fidelity to the covenant and the hope of restoration through grace.

verses.text: The boar from the forest ravages it, and all that move in the field feed on it.
verses.comment: The wild boar likely symbolizes foreign invaders threatening God’s people—a warning calling for repentance and a return to fidelity and true worship.

verses.text: Return, O God of Hosts; look down from heaven and see, and care for this vine,
verses.comment: The prayer calls God to restore and tend His people, prefiguring Christ’s role as the divine caretaker and mediator.

verses.text: the stock that your right hand planted, and for the son whom you made strong for yourself.
verses.comment: The 'son' also carries messianic overtones, often interpreted as foretelling Christ, the true Son of God, who fulfills the purpose of Israel and David’s line.

verses.text: It is burned with fire, it is cut down; they perish at the rebuke of your face.
verses.comment: Fire and destruction signal the severity of judgment for unfaithfulness. This calls believers to repentance through sacramental reconciliation and faithfulness to God’s commands.

verses.text: Let your hand be upon the man of your right hand, the son of man whom you have made strong for yourself.
verses.comment: This points prophetically to Christ, the 'Son of Man,' at God’s right hand—echoing Divine authority and mediatorship promised in the messianic hope.

verses.text: Then we will not turn away from you; revive us, and we will call on your name.
verses.comment: True revival comes through God’s initiative, calling for continual conversion and faith—the heart of a vibrant communion with God, as Christ institutes in His church.

verses.text: Restore us, O LORD God of Hosts; let your face shine upon us, that we may be saved.
verses.comment: The psalm closes with a plea for God’s saving presence, echoing themes of restoration and grace. The repeated invocation emphasizes communal intercession, a core principle of the apostolic faith and the lived experience of the ancient Church.
